html: It seems that such books for beginners do not exist. Only the basic knowledge of algebraic field extensions would be essential. That can be found in e.g. Lang's Algebra. Cohen's A Course in Computational Algebraic Number Theory could be useful, but even that contains much material that is not needed here. However, it has a good collection of references to literature.

html: It seems that you are thinking very much along the lines I wanted to introduce. There may be one difference, though. The name Bound looks like you only wanted to deal with the case of bounded functions. I think it would be useful to allow all extended reals as bounds, also the limiting infinite values. So, we could write Limits(0, oo) if we only know that the limiting (or accumulation) values are non-negative. That is why I suggested the name Limits (there are two of them).
text: It seems that you are thinking very much along the lines I wanted to introduce. There may be one difference, though. The name ``Bound`` looks like you only wanted to deal with the case of bounded functions. I think it would be useful to allow all extended reals as bounds, also the limiting infinite values. So, we could write ``Limits(0, oo)`` if we only know that the limiting (or accumulation) values are non-negative. That is why I suggested the name ``Limits`` (there are two of them).

html: I would also have expected IV(1, 3). I also think that finite sets need not be involved (at least to begin with). Division is a bit problematic. If the divisor interval includes 0, I think the result should be Limits(-oo, oo). But in some cases it might be possible to obtain better results for actual limits of a function f, if we can prove that abs(f) is greater than a strictly positive limit. Hence the calculus of limits should not be used mechanically to find limits of quotients.
text: I would also have expected ``IV(1, 3)``. I also think that finite sets need not be involved (at least to begin with).  Division is a bit problematic. If the divisor interval includes 0, I think the result should be ``Limits(-oo, oo)``. But in some cases it might be possible to obtain better results for actual limits of a function ``f``, if we can prove that ``abs(f)`` is greater than a strictly positive limit. Hence the calculus of limits should not be used mechanically to find limits of quotients.

html: The PR looks promising, though I haven't studied it in detail yet. Defining Limits as a subclass of Interval is useful if it saves the trouble of redefining some methods such as contains. There is one thing that I would like to do differently, namely the end points. The limit (or accumulation) point set is always closed so there appears to be no reason to use open intervals. I think that the end points should always be included, so left_open and right_open could be omitted from the interface of __new__. They could be set to False in the actual constructor call (line 237). In particular, there should be no need to set them True for infinite end points. (That is currently done anyway in Interval.__new__, but I think that is a mistake.)
text: The PR looks promising, though I haven't studied it in detail yet. Defining Limits as a subclass of Interval is useful if it saves the trouble of redefining some methods such as ``contains``. There is one thing that I would like to do differently, namely the end points. The limit (or accumulation) point set is always closed so there appears to be no reason to use open intervals. I think that the end points should always be included, so ``left_open`` and ``right_open`` could be omitted from the interface of ``__new__``. They could be set to ``False`` in the actual constructor call (line 237). In particular, there should be no need to set them ``True`` for infinite end points. (That is currently done anyway in ``Interval.__new__``, but I think that is a mistake.)

html: I think that 'Limits' is becoming mature (though not necessarily complete yet). I originally intended it as an aid to describe the set of accumulation values of a real function at a point, finite or infinite, where no limit exists. This set is a closed subset of the space of extended real numbers. It always has a maximum and a minimum, possibly infinite, and then some points in between, possibly all or none.

```
>>> limit((-1)**n, n, oo)
NotImplementedError
```
But from [Wolfram Alpha here](http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=limit%28%28-1%29**n+%2B+1%2C+n%2C+oo%29) the answer is given in a form as we have `Limits` sort of computation. I think this is an example that could very well be treated (though perhaps not necessarily immediately). It is a basic example where there are only two accumulation points (for n an integer). Is value could be Limits(-1, 1).
AccumulationLimits sounds fairly good to me, too. It is quite descriptive. However, it is a bit longer than I would have preferred. I'll still try to continue the search.
Extending these concepts to the complex domain might be feasible. But I think that could wait until we have more experience with the implications of this PR.

html: I have been trying to think the naming of Limits but not very successfully, I'm afraid. If we add Accumulation as in AccumulationLimits, it would perhaps be possible to use Bounds instead of Limits. I have felt that Bounds alone could be confused with bounds and boundedness of a function, but the addition of Accumulation would change that. So my best choice now is AccumulationBounds. It is longer than I would have expected but fortunately there is the short angle bracket notation for practical use.
text: I have been trying to think the naming of ``Limits`` but not very successfully, I'm afraid. If we add ``Accumulation`` as in ``AccumulationLimits``, it would perhaps be possible to use ``Bounds`` instead of ``Limits``. I have felt that ``Bounds`` alone could be confused with bounds and boundedness of a function, but the addition of ``Accumulation`` would change that. So my best choice now is ``AccumulationBounds``. It is longer than I would have expected but fortunately there is the short angle bracket notation for practical use.

Hi, @jksuom I am looking at the issue sympy/sympy#9980 . Though there is no link to any wikipedia article to exactly what exactly aktech wanted to implement. But i quote some of the comments:

Please note that it's not just about representing rectangular or polar regions, we should be able to perform all the set operations in argand plane, & ComplexRegion is a good candidate for that.
To be concise: ComplexRegion is analogous to Interval and S.Complexes is analogous to S.Reals in complex & real domains respectively.

Here is the link to that comment
the first line indicates ComplexRegion is intended to represent and complex region, the leads me to say: "I think it may be necessary to have Lambda expression". Example,
Like if we want to represent any complex-region, sets argument would just indicate the intervals with which the variables ( x and y or r and theta(this restricts to polar region) are bounded) , while Lambda( (_x, _y), x + I*y**2)) here the lambda expression is not simply default but something different from standard.

On the other hand if what is not to done with ComplexRegion (i.e it just is thought to represent the standard regions like rectangular regions or polar regions then i think removing Lambda from API sounds good (as you already suggested in your comments).
text:
Hi, @jksuom I am looking at the issue https://github.com/sympy/sympy/issues/9980 . Though there is no link to any wikipedia article to exactly what exactly `aktech` wanted to implement. But i quote some of the comments:
> Please note that it's not just about representing rectangular or polar regions, we should be able to perform all the set operations in argand plane, & ComplexRegion is a good candidate for that.
To be concise: ComplexRegion is analogous to Interval and S.Complexes is analogous to S.Reals in complex & real domains respectively.


[Here is the link to that comment](https://github.com/sympy/sympy/issues/9980#issuecomment-151549749) 
the first line indicates `ComplexRegion` is intended to represent and complex region, the leads me to say: "I think it may be necessary to have `Lambda` expression". Example, 
Like if we want to represent any complex-region, `sets` argument would just indicate the intervals with which the variables ( `x` and `y` or `r` and `theta`(this restricts to polar region) are bounded) , while `Lambda( (_x, _y), x + I*y**2))` here the lambda expression is not simply default but something different from standard.

On the other hand if what is not to done with `ComplexRegion` (i.e it just is thought to represent the standard regions like `rectangular regions ` or `polar regions` then i think removing `Lambda` from API sounds good (as you already suggested in your comments).

html: Apparently aktech has started from the idea of defining something like intervals in the complex plane. But it is not easy to decide what these should be. The topology of the plane is much more involved than that of the line. An interval in a line is any connected subset, while in the plane there is a vast number of connected sets. Technically, many of those could be represented by lambda expressions with two real parameters that range over some intervals. But there are many ways of parametrising even a single set, and still we should be able to think of these as being the same 'region' of the plane. That would be hard if a lambda expression is included as an essential part of the structure.

Technically, many of those could be represented by lambda expressions with two real parameters that range over some intervals. But there are many ways of parametrising even a single set, and still we should be able to think of these as being the same 'region' of the plane. That would be hard if a lambda expression is included as an essential part of the structure.

Jan 23 18:22
Nothing much seems to have been done. So I think is still valid.
jksuom
Jan 23 18:36
Q 2. As to the implementation, what I had in mind would probably not involve any new mathematics. It could just be some kind of refactorisation of the current implementation, at least to begin with. I wanted to point out that there are essentially two types of limits. 1) Those that can be derived from power series and 2) the others. In the current implementation those solvable by power series are treated in an offhand way, called 'heuristic' if I recall it correctly. I think that the limit method should begin with a study of possibility of power series expansions of the functions involved. That would suffice for meromorphic functions whose only singularities are poles. Only if the function has an essential singularity with no power series expansion, should the more advanced methods (Gruntz' algorithm) be applied.
Another matter that I may not have mentioned in that issue is that Gruntz' algorithm is essentially intended for real functions. It may occasionally be possible to treat complex functions by, for example, taking their real and imaginary parts separately, but in the current implementation that seems to lead to errors in some cases.
jksuom
Jan 23 18:45
So the plan could be this: First study the structure of the current implementation, then refactor. At the same time, or afterwards, you could also fix some bugs that will probably reveal themselves in the process.

html: I found a link to a pdf-file containing the manual in Maple's home page. It was a bit hard to read as it did render very slowly. (Maybe they also have a html-version, for paying customers.) It seems that there are four types of limits, called 'left', 'right', 'real' and 'complex'. The first two correspond to '-' and '+' in SymPy, and 'real' is apparently the two combined. I did not read the details but I think that they all deal with limits on the real line at a real point (including oo and -oo). The last form is presumably concerned with limits in the topology of the complex plane at any complex point (perhaps also zoo).

html: From the point of view of implementation I think there are only two basically different types of limits.The two directional limits are determined by the same method, moving the limit point to oo by such a mapping that the limit becomes the 'left' limit at oo. And the third is just a combination. Only the complex limit has different implementation. It should be the more elementary one to implement as it is based on power (or possibly Laurent) series expansions.

html: The existence of a "complex limit" is conceptually very close to 'is_analytic_at' , or 'is_meromorphic_at' if also zoo is accepted as a bona fide value. Depending on the implementation of the latter functions there may be a little difference in some cases. Consider, for example, f(x) = sin(x)/x. It is undefined at x = 0 in SymPy (nan), but it has finite limit 1, and if it is extended by assigning that value to f(0, the function will become analytic at 0. So, it appears that the decision of using is_analytic_at instead of (complex) limit would depend on whether such an extension should be done automatically inside SymPy or not.
text: The existence of a "complex limit" is conceptually very close to 'is_analytic_at' , or 'is_meromorphic_at'  if also ``zoo`` is accepted as a bona fide value. Depending on the implementation of the latter functions there may be a little difference in some cases. Consider, for example, ``f(x) = sin(x)/x``. It is undefined at x = 0 in SymPy (``nan``), but it has finite limit 1, and if it is extended by assigning that value to ``f(0``, the function will become analytic at 0. So, it appears that the decision of using ``is_analytic_at`` instead of (complex) limit would depend on whether such an extension should be done automatically inside SymPy or not.

html: A neighbourhood of a point in the complex plane is a set containing an open disk centred at the point. So, loosely speaking, it is a set containing 'all sufficiently close points'. Earlier it was often demanded that a neighbourhood be open, but that proved usually not necessary and sometimes inconvenient.
text: A *neighbourhood* of a point in the complex plane is a set containing an open disk centred at the point. So, loosely speaking, it is a set containing 'all sufficiently close points'. Earlier it was often demanded that a neighbourhood be open, but that proved usually not necessary and sometimes inconvenient.

html: A function is analytic at a point a in the complex plane, if it is defined in a neighbourhood of a and can be represented there as the sum of a convergent series in powers of z - a. The power series converges in a disk, and its sum can be represented by similar series centred at other points of the disk. Hence the sum is analytic in the disk, and therefore a function analytic at a point is always analytic at all points in a neighbourhood of the point. (This means that the set where a function is analytic is always open.)
text: A function is *analytic* at a point  a  in the complex plane, if it is defined in a neighbourhood of  a  and can be represented there as the sum of a convergent series in powers of  z - a. The power series converges in a disk, and its sum can be represented by similar series centred at other points of the disk. Hence the sum is analytic in the disk, and therefore a function analytic at a point is always analytic at all points in a neighbourhood of the point. (This means that the set where a function is analytic is always open.)

html: A function f is meromorphic at a point a if there are functions g and h analytic at a and such that f(z) = g(z)/h(z) at all points z different from a in a neighbourhood of a, at which f need not be defined. Note that h may have a (multiple) zero at a but, if it is not the constant zero, there is a neighbourhood of a where h is different from zero at all points other than a.
text: A function  f  is *meromorphic* at a point  a  if there are functions   g   and  h  analytic at  a  and such that  f(z) = g(z)/h(z)  at all points  z  different from  a  in a neighbourhood of  a, at which  f  need not be defined. Note that  h  may have a (multiple) zero at  a  but, if it is not the constant zero, there is a neighbourhood of  a  where  h  is different from zero at all points other than  a.

html: So, your conclusions about a pole at z = 0 and an essential (non-meromorphic) singularity at z = 2 are correct. Only the behaviour in a neighbourhood matters.
text: So, your conclusions about a pole at ``z = 0`` and an essential (non-meromorphic) singularity at ``z = 2`` are correct. Only the behaviour in a neighbourhood matters.

html: It seems necessary to introduce the order function of a meromorphic function at a point (related to Order but not the same). It should probably be a global function  order(f, x, a)  implemented outside core. Its values are integers, negative at a pole ( and oo for f = 0). At an essential singularity it should probably return None. (The value is useless for computations in any case.)

html: It probably means that the function should walk the expression tree and call itself recursively. The order of a Mul is easy: it is the sum of the orders of its arguments. Add is harder. We have to find the minimal order of the arguments. If minimum value occurs only once, then that is returned. Otherwise we have to look into the power series developments of the arguments to see if some cancelling would occur.

text: Can things like "order of an entire function", "mittag leffler's expansion" be possibly be implemented in SymPy?

html: Those are pretty much of theoretical use only. Something like the order of an entire functions is implicitly handled by gruntz though that is restricted to (positive) real axis in principle. (Only few functions known to SymPy are entire.)  Mittag-Leffler expansions of many functions can be found explicitly, but a general algorithm seems hard to implement.

html: There are two types of missing parts, those for which there is usable pseudocode in Bronstein's book and those that only have verbal descriptions. Although the amount of actual code lines may not be significantly different in the two missing areas, those with no pseudocode are much harder to implement. I did solve that problem by trying to add comments explaining the procedure. That was pretty tedious, but also necessary for myself to see what had to be done.  You can probably get an idea of what is involved by comparing my PR with the book.

html: The algebraic part is really hard. That is explained in two texts that I find more readable than Bronstein's papers on that matter, Davenport's book of 1981 and Trager's thesis of 1984. The former may may not be available for free (there is a copy in Amazon) but Trager's paper should be in the net. You could take a look at that. Wikipedia says that "The case of purely algebraic functions was solved and implemented in Reduce by James H. Davenport." That should not be taken too literally. In "State of the Implementation" Davenport writes: "While the theory is complete, the actual REDUCE-2 implementation is incomplete in several areas." Then he goes on to enumerate the missing parts, of which the first one is "The treatment of algebraics other than those which can be expressed in terms of square roots." (All this is here to convince you that completing the algebraic part is no simple matter.)

html: Let K be a field and f a polynomial in K[X] having the roots x1,…,xnx_1, \ldots, x_nx​1​​,…,x​n​​ in an extension field L of K. If g = p/q is a rational fraction in K(X) whose denominator q and f are coprime, then the g(xi)=p(xi)/q(xi)g(x_i) = p(x_i)/q(x_i)g(x​i​​)=p(x​i​​)/q(x​i​​) are well defined elements of L and their sum ∑ig(xi)\sum_i g(x_i)∑​i​​g(x​i​​) is called a root sum. Its basic property is that it is invariant under all permutations of the roots xix_ix​i​​. By Galois theory it follows that it is actually an element of K (assuming that f is separable). (This reduction has not yet been implemented in SymPy.)
text: Let  K be a field and  f  a polynomial in  K[X] having the roots $$x_1, \ldots, x_n$$ in an extension field  L  of  K. If  g = p/q  is a rational fraction in  K(X) whose denominator  q  and  f  are coprime, then the $$g(x_i) = p(x_i)/q(x_i)$$ are well defined elements of  L  and their sum $$\sum_i g(x_i)$$ is called a root sum. Its basic property is that it is invariant under all permutations of the roots $$x_i$$. By Galois theory it follows that it is actually an element of  K  (assuming that  f  is separable). (This reduction has not yet been implemented in SymPy.)

html: Trigonometric functions and their inverses can be reduced to exponentials and logarithms over the complex domain. If one wants to work in the domain of real numbers (with no complex coefficients), then it suffices to add tangents and arctangents. (This was discussed e.g. by Risch in his 1979 paper.) So, in principle, trigonometric functions and their inverses can be integrated with exps and logs alone, but the results do not look so nice in general.

html: Good morning (or afternoon, actually. I only now found time for this.) Davenport's proposed implementation has been superseded by Trager's improvements. Puiseux series, in particular, are not needed. They are inconvenient because of the algebraic extensions the base field that are necessary in the computations but not in the final results. (This is loosely analogous to using complex partial fraction decomposition for integrating 1/(1 + x**2). We get a sum of two logarithms with explicit I's, but in the real domain we obtain atan(x).) Otherwise, Davenport's book may be a good reference for some more theoretical points.
text: Good morning (or afternoon, actually. I only now found time for this.) Davenport's proposed implementation has been superseded by Trager's improvements. Puiseux series, in particular, are not needed. They are inconvenient because of the algebraic extensions the base field that are necessary in the computations but not in the final results. (This is loosely analogous to using complex partial fraction decomposition for integrating `1/(1 + x**2)`. We get a sum of two logarithms with explicit `I`'s, but in the real domain we obtain `atan(x)`.) Otherwise, Davenport's book may be a good reference for some more theoretical points.

html: Good morning. I would say that it is theoretical in the sense that it attempts to define exactly what integration in finite terms should mean. He even introduces recursive functions and Gödel numbering to make these concepts exact in the spirit of Church's thesis. From the practical point of view, i.e., for the construction of actual integration algorithms there does not seem to be anything new. The methods he presents appear to be the same as elsewhere. I think that his Main Theorem only deals with the case of transcendental extensions. As Trager's thesis is on algebraic extensions, I don't think he has any use for that paper by Risch.

html: Good morning, Gaurav. Can you be a little more specific about what part you don't quite understand?  Broadly speaking, the purpose ot the function is to separate real and complex roots of the real polynomial q, and combine the complex roots (and the corresponding terms) pairwise. The pseudocode is very condense and relies on constructions that are not implemented in SymPy, namely RootSums over a pair of roots of a pair of equations. The implementation attempts to proceed by explicitly solving the equations, but that does not seem quite satisfactory.

html: I would like to interpret the word "limited" in the following way. Normally, integrating an element fff of a differential field KKK means that one should construct an extension field that would contain the integral. "limited" means that no extension should be constructed. Instead, the task is made easier to solve by allowing that fff can be modified by extracting some linear combination of some given elements wiw_iw​i​​. This means that the form of the resulting integral is limited to a combination of elements of KKK and integrals of the wiw_iw​i​​. I think that this is very close to what you are suggesting.
text: I would like to interpret the word "limited" in the following way. Normally, integrating an element $$f$$ of a differential field $$K$$ means that one should construct an extension field that would contain the integral. "limited" means that no extension should be constructed. Instead, the task is made easier to solve by allowing that $$f$$  can be modified by extracting some linear combination of some given elements $$w_i$$. This means that the form of the resulting integral is limited to a combination of elements of $$K$$ and integrals of the $$w_i$$.  I think that this is very close to what you are suggesting.

html:
Normally, integrating an element f of a differential field K means that one should construct an extension field that would contain the integral.

In this statement, we have to find an extension of KKK just so it contains the (finite) logarithms stated in Liouvelle's theorem? (the Liouville's theorem states that elementary antiderivatives, if they exist, must be in the same differential field as the function, plus possibly a finite number of logarithms.)
text:
> Normally, integrating an element f of a differential field K means that one should construct an extension field that would contain the integral.

In this statement, we have to find an extension of $$K$$ just so it contains the (finite) *logarithms* stated in Liouvelle's theorem? (the Liouville's theorem states that elementary antiderivatives, if they exist, must be in the same differential field as the function, plus possibly a finite number of logarithms.)

html: Liouville's theorem deals with integrals (or antiderivatives) in elementary extensions. That is, of course, what we would usually be working with. So, in that case, we will get logarithms of elements of KKK.
text: Liouville's theorem deals with integrals (or antiderivatives) in elementary extensions. That is, of course, what we would usually be working with. So, in that case, we will get logarithms of elements of $$K$$.

It is not necessary to start with limited_integrate_reduce at this point since param_rischDEwill do the reduction. This way there will be less code to test. It seems that limited_integrate_reduce is intended as a starting point to a (hopefully) more efficient implementation where the special nature of the problem is observed and certain shortcuts are taken as indicated in the book on p. 245.

text: What is the definition of monomial over $$k$$? where $$k$$ being a differential field.

html: It is defined on p. 3.4.1. The definition is specific to differential fields. It is different from the standard definition in algebra so that may be confusing. The definition says that a monomial is an element t of a differential extension K /k that is transcendental over k and such that the element Dt of K is in k[t], in other words, Dt is a polynomial in t with coefficients in k.
text: It is defined on p. 3.4.1. The definition is specific to differential fields. It is different from the standard definition in algebra so that may be confusing. The definition says that a monomial is an element  t  of a differential extension  K /k  that is transcendental over  k  *and* such that the element  Dt  of K is in  k[t], in other words,  Dt is a polynomial in  t with coefficients in  k.

html: Parametric Risch DE's are solved by recursion on the levels. Those prde_... routines work on a single level with a 'base' differential field kkk and a differential extension K=k(t)K = k(t)K=k(t) where ttt is a 'monomial' as defined in the book. KKK itself may be the 'base' for another extension defined in the DifferentialExtension structure, but those routines only work on one level at a time. Solving the Risch DE on a certain level will generally depend on the ability to solve similar equations on lower levels of the same total differential extension.
text: Parametric Risch DE's are solved by recursion on the levels. Those `prde_...` routines work on a single level with a 'base' differential field $$k$$ and a differential extension $$K = k(t)$$ where $$t$$ is a 'monomial' as defined in the book. $$K$$ itself may be the 'base' for another extension defined in the `DifferentialExtension` structure, but those routines only work on one level at a time. Solving the Risch DE on a certain level will generally depend on the ability to solve similar equations on lower levels of the same total differential extension.

    # Fd can be set to any non-zero Poly

    G = [(fa, fd)] + G

The return value h, A of the param_rischDEcall consists of a list h of r elements of k(t) (components of solutions) and a matrix Awhose null space elements(c1, ..., cm, d1, ..., dr) give all solutions y = Sum(di*hi) to the parametric Risch DE. The return value of limited_integrate is not explicitly defined, but apparently it should be y, [-c2, ..., -cm] with c1 = 1(or, equivalently, -y, [c2, ..., cm] with c1 = -1). In some cases there could be many such solutions. I'm not sure if all of them should be returned. The algorithm in the book seems to expect only one, if it exists.

html: So the plan for the simplified limited_integrate is this. Start with param_rischDE(Fa, Fd, G) where Fa, Fd are 0, 1 (polynomials) and G = [(fa, fd)] + G as above. Get h, A. Set V = A.nullspace(). Filter out solutions with first coefficient zero: V = [v for v in V if v[0] != 0]. If no vector remains, return nothing (probably None could do). Else take first vector and normalize by dividing with the negative of the first element. Get [-1, c1, ..., cm, d1, ..., dr]. Return -Sum(dj*hj), [c1, ..., cm] (where Sum should be transformed to an (ha, hd) pair if that is expected, I didn't check). (This can be on top of limited_integrate. The rest of the code can be activated later if desired.)
text: So the plan for the simplified `limited_integrate` is this. Start with `param_rischDE(Fa, Fd, G)` where `Fa, Fd` are 0, 1 (polynomials) and `G = [(fa, fd)] + G`  as above. Get `h, A`. Set `V = A.nullspace()`. Filter out solutions with first coefficient zero: `V = [v for v in V if v[0] != 0]`. If no vector remains, return nothing (probably None could do). Else take first vector and normalize by dividing with the negative of the first element. Get `[-1, c1, ..., cm, d1, ..., dr]`. Return `-Sum(dj*hj), [c1, ..., cm]` (where Sum should be transformed to an `(ha, hd)` pair if that is expected, I didn't check). (This can be on top of `limited_integrate`. The rest of the code can be activated later if desired.)

text: I used the name 'derivative in the field' to denote elements of the form $$Dg$$ for some $$g$$ in the field in question. ($$k(t)$$ in this case.) six was imported from wrong directory. This is the fix from github:
```
diff --git a/setuptools/py27compat.py b/setuptools/py27compat.py
index 701283c..2985011 100644
--- a/setuptools/py27compat.py
+++ b/setuptools/py27compat.py
@@ -4,7 +4,7 @@ Compatibility Support for Python 2.7 and earlier
 
 import platform
 
-import six
+from setuptools.extern import six
```

html: I think that Aaron noted something to the effect that Poly is an oddity among polys classes. I think it would be reasonable to set ring=EX at least for now. It is, after all, a valid domain. Having two types of matrices in the same module is annoying. Eventually fractions coded as (fa, fd) pairs should be replaced with proper polys objects (probably FracElements) and polynomials would be of type PolyElement. Then the EX domain would not be needed, but it would do no harm either.
text: I think that Aaron noted something to the effect that `Poly` is an oddity among polys classes. I think it would be reasonable to set `ring=EX` at least for now. Eventually fractions coded as `(fa, fd)` pairs should be replaced with proper polys objects (probably `FracElement`s) and polynomials would be of type `PolyElement`. Then the `EX` domain would not be needed, but it would do no harm either.

html: Good morning. I have been thinking a bit about the DE0 object. I'm not sure that another modified copy of DE would be practical. It is true that increment/decrement_level take a little bit of time but that is negligible in comparison with the rest of the processing. Also, DE has grown rather big, it combines different kinds of data, and it may become justifiable to separate its mutable parts eventually into another object, but I don't think time should be spent on that now. It is important to add the missing code and that should be possible with the current DE structure.

html: Those equations are for the highest term yntny_n t^ny​n​​t​n​​ of the solution only. The equations for lower terms are similar but the right hand side is more complicated. Instead of Dq+bq=∑ciqiDq + bq = \sum c_i q_iDq+bq=∑c​i​​q​i​​ we have an equation of the top of p. 238 where the highest term of hhh has to be computed following the same procedure. The general degree nnn term ∑djnfjntn\sum d_{jn} f_{jn} t^n∑d​jn​​f​jn​​t​n​​ of qqq is now saved and the lower degree polynomial h∈k[t]h \in k[t]h∈k[t] takes the place of qqq. From the equation on top of p. 238 the highest order term on hhh is now solved and saved in the same way. You can think of hhh as the new qqq, only of lower degree and new equation with additional terms on the right hand side. So, to answer your question, the equations 7.22 and 723, in exactly that form, are solved only once, but there are analogous equations for each iii from n−1n - 1n−1 to 000.
text: Those equations are for the highest term $$y_n t^n$$ of the solution only. The equations for lower terms are similar but the right hand side is more complicated. Instead of $$Dq + bq = \sum c_i q_i$$ we have an equation of the top of p. 238 where the highest term of $$h$$ has to be computed following the same procedure. The general degree $$n$$ term $$\sum d_{jn} f_{jn} t^n$$ of $$q$$ is now saved and the lower degree polynomial $$h \in k[t]$$ takes the place of $$q$$. From the equation on top of p. 238 the highest order term on $$h$$ is now solved and saved in the same way. You can think of $$h$$ as the new $$q$$, only of lower degree and new equation with additional terms on the right hand side. So, to answer your question, the equations 7.22 and 723, in exactly that form, are solved only once, but there are analogous equations for each $$i$$ from $$n - 1$$ to $$0$$.

It is the equation for the highest term of hhh that corresponds to 7.22 and 7.23. text: Perhaps I should remind that the equation on top of p. 238 is for a *polynomial* solution $$h$$. It is analogous to Eq. 7.16, and there we have $$b$$ also in the hyperexponential case. It is the equation for the highest term of $$h$$ that corresponds to 7.22 and 7.23. Its solutions are elements of $$k$$, i.e., *constant polynomials*, and there we have $$b + i Dt/t$$ in the hyperexponential case.

html: It looks like it is time to consider reality questions (trig. functions, atan). I think some changes in DifferentialExtension.__init__ could be practical before new code is added. First, lists like E_K, L_K and the new ones could be combined in a single list with one entry at each level recording the type 'exp', 'log', 'tan', 'atan' and finally 'alg'. That would contain the same information as the separate lists. Then the code itself could be reorganized by collecting those sections that inspect and rewrite pows and logs into separate methods like _rewrite_powsand _rewrite_logs. Then it would be easier to add code for tan and atan (after other trig. functions have been rewritten).
text: It looks like it is time to consider reality questions (trig. functions, atan). I think some changes in `DifferentialExtension.__init__` could be practical before new code is added. First, lists like `E_K`, `L_K` and the new ones could be combined in a single list with one entry at each level recording the type 'exp', 'log', 'tan', 'atan' and finally 'alg'. That would contain the same information as the separate lists. Then the code itself could be reorganized by collecting those sections that inspect and rewrite pows and logs into separate methods like `_rewrite_pows`and `_rewrite_logs`. Then it would be easier to add code for tan and atan (after other trig. functions have been rewritten).

html: No, that is not a basis, in general. A basis for CCC over QQQ is finite only if the extension isalgebraic, and even then the generators do not usually suffice for a basis. For example, C=Q(2+3)C = Q(\sqrt{2} + \sqrt{3})C=Q(√​2​​​+√​3​​​) has a single generator and dimension 4 over Q. One of its bases is 1,2,3,61, \sqrt{2}, \sqrt{3}, \sqrt{6}1,√​2​​​,√​3​​​,√​6​​​. For transcendental generators (such as π\piπ) all powers are linearly independent so any basis is infinite.
text: No, that is not a basis, in general. A basis for $$C$$ over $$Q$$ is finite only if the extension isalgebraic, and even then the generators do not usually suffice for a basis. For example, $$C = Q(\sqrt{2} + \sqrt{3})$$ has a single generator and dimension 4 over Q. One of its bases is $$1, \sqrt{2}, \sqrt{3}, \sqrt{6}$$. For transcendental generators (such as $$\pi$$) all powers are linearly independent so any basis is infinite.

That will create domains extending an algebraic number field with transcendental elements (or elements that are not known to be algebraic). We should probably treat all transcendental constants as algebraically independent since possible relations are hard to detect. (That is analogous to the zero detection problem in EX domain.)

html: The constant field is C=K(t1,…,tn)C = K(t_1, \ldots, t_n)C=K(t​1​​,…,t​n​​) where KKK is an algebraic number field and the tit_it​i​​ are transcendental constants (assumed algebraically independent). The field KKK should probably be of type AlgebraicField (not FractionField).
text: The constant field is $$C = K(t_1, \ldots, t_n)$$ where $$K$$ is an algebraic number field and the $$t_i$$ are transcendental constants (assumed algebraically independent). The field $$K$$ should probably be of type `AlgebraicField` (not `FractionField`).

html: The elements of CCC are fractions of polynomials in the tit_it​i​​ with coefficients in KKK. The first task is to find those fractions (and KKK). That is probably best done with sfield from the constant list (with extension=True).
text: The elements of $$C$$ are fractions of polynomials in the $$t_i$$ with coefficients in $$K$$. The first task is to find those fractions (and $$K$$). That is probably best done with `sfield` from the constant list (with `extension=True`).

html: Once the representations of the constants as fractions are found, it is possible to proceed by first finding the linear relations over KKK. The fraction fields K(t1,…,tn)K(t_1, \ldots, t_n)K(t​1​​,…,t​n​​) are infinite dimensional. If n=1n = 1n=1, then one basis over KKK is formed by powers of t=t1t = t_1t=t​1​​ and fractions of the form tk/p(t)nt^k/p(t)^nt​k​​/p(t)​n​​ where ppp an irreducible polynomial and k<degpk < \deg{p}k<degp (as follows from the partial fraction expansion). That can be iterated to obtain a basis in case of several generators.
text: Once the representations of the constants as fractions are found, it is possible to proceed by first finding the linear relations over $$K$$. The fraction fields $$K(t_1, \ldots, t_n)$$ are infinite dimensional. If $$n = 1$$, then one basis over $$K$$ is formed by powers of $$t = t_1$$ and fractions of the form $$t^k/p(t)^n$$ where $$p$$ an irreducible polynomial and $$k < \deg{p}$$ (as follows from the partial fraction expansion). That can be iterated to obtain a basis in case of several generators.

html: The full basis is quite awkward to deal with. Fortunately, there is a simpler way to find the linear relations over KKK. The denominators of all fractions can be made equal to their least common multiple. Then linear relations with coefficients in KKK become relations between the numerator polynomials only, and there we have a manageable basis formed by monomials.
text: The full basis is quite awkward to deal with. Fortunately, there is a simpler way to find the linear relations over $$K$$. The denominators of all fractions can be made equal to their least common multiple. Then linear relations with coefficients in $$K$$ become relations between the numerator polynomials only, and there we have a manageable basis formed by monomials.

html: I'm not sure that there would be much use for the function base_Q. I have been speaking of bases for the purpose of having a theoretical background, but what we should actually need are the linear relations ∑i=1nrifi=0\sum_{i=1}^n r_i f_i = 0∑​i=1​n​​r​i​​f​i​​=0 where fif_if​i​​ are elements of a function field such as those appearing in the structure theorem: fi=Dt,Dt/t,Dt/(t2+1)f_i = Dt, Dt/t, Dt/(t^2 + 1)f​i​​=Dt,Dt/t,Dt/(t​2​​+1). (The derivative operator DDD is used to find these elements but otherwise it has no role here, so there is no need to separate constants from non-constants.) The task is to find those linear relations where the coefficients rir_ir​i​​ are rational numbers. The computation depends on the existence of some basis over QQQ but the result should be a matrix of rational entries such that the rational relations are exactly the elements of the rational solution space of the matrix.
text: I'm not sure that there would be much use for the function `base_Q`. I have been speaking of bases for the purpose of having a theoretical background, but what we should actually need are the linear relations $$\sum_{i=1}^n r_i f_i = 0$$ where $$f_i$$ are elements of a function field such as those appearing in the structure theorem: $$f_i = Dt, Dt/t, Dt/(t^2 + 1)$$. (The derivative operator $$D$$ is used to find these elements but otherwise it has no role here, so there is no need to separate constants from non-constants.) The task is to find those linear relations where the coefficients $$r_i$$ are rational numbers. The computation depends on the existence of some basis over $$Q$$ but the result should be a matrix of rational entries such that the rational relations are exactly the elements of the rational solution space of the matrix.

html: The computation could be done in two phases assuming that the fif_if​i​​ are fractions over an algebraic number field KKK. First, a matrix with entries in KKK is found such that its solution space would consist of all linear relations where the rir_ir​i​​ are in KKK. Then the finite basis of KKK over QQQ is considered, and the matrix is replaced with another matrix with rational entries.
text: The computation could be done in two phases assuming that the $$f_i$$ are fractions over an algebraic number field $$K$$. First, a matrix with entries in $$K$$ is found such that its solution space would consist of all linear relations where the $$r_i$$ are in $$K$$. Then the finite basis of $$K$$ over $$Q$$ is considered, and the matrix is replaced with another matrix with rational entries.

That can be obtained by feeding them simultaneously to `sfield` (with `extension=True`). It will apply the `parallel_polys_from...` methods to find a field containing all the fractions.

html: Given a list F of elements of K(…)K(\ldots)K(…) (the names of the generators are not needed) we can find the lcm denom of the f.denom for f in F (which is a PolyElement). Then we can find the list of new numerators nums = [denom.exquo(f.denom)*f.numer for f in F]. Then we find the set monoms of monomials that appear in the numerators as the union of num.monoms() for num in nums. Each monomial corresponds to a row in the matrix of entries in KKK giving the relations. The elements of F correspond to the columns and the entries are num._get_coeff(m) for num in nums and for m in monoms. (The order of the rows is irrelevant since the permuted matrices have the same nullspace. The columns correspond to the elements of F.)
text: Given a list `F` of elements of $$K(\ldots)$$ (the names of the generators are not needed) we can find the lcm `denom` of the `f.denom for f in F` (which is a `PolyElement`). Then we can find the list of new numerators `nums =  [denom.exquo(f.denom)*f.numer for f in F]`. Then we find the set `monoms` of monomials that appear in the numerators as the union of `num.monoms() for num in nums`. Each monomial corresponds to a row in the matrix of entries in $$K$$ giving the relations. The elements of `F` correspond to the columns and the entries are `num._get_coeff(m) for num in nums` and `for m in monoms`. (The order of the rows is irrelevant since the permuted matrices have the same nullspace. The columns correspond to the elements of `F`.)

html: If the functions fjf_jf​j​​ have algebraic coefficients in a number field KKK, then the above procedure leads to a matrix with entries in KKK such that the vectors (rj)(r_j)(r​j​​) in its null space are exactly those that satisfy the linear relation ∑rjfj=0\sum r_j f_j = 0∑r​j​​f​j​​=0. That includes not only rational relations but also those where ri∈Kr_i\in Kr​i​​∈K if we use SymPy's nullspace for finding the relations. In order to get only rational solutions the matrix with entries in KKK must be replaced with another one with rational entries. Before explaining how to do that I'll write out the equations that led to the above relation matrix.
text: If the functions $$f_j$$ have algebraic coefficients in a number field $$K$$, then the above procedure leads to a matrix with entries in $$K$$ such that the vectors $$(r_j)$$ in its null space are exactly those that satisfy the linear relation $$\sum r_j f_j = 0$$. That includes not only rational relations but also those where $$r_i\in K$$  if we use SymPy's  `nullspace` for finding the relations. In order to get only rational solutions the matrix with entries in $$K$$ must be replaced with another one with rational entries. Before explaining how to do that I'll write out the equations that led to the above relation matrix.

html: We start by writing out the fjf_jf​j​​ as fractions nj/dn_j/dn​j​​/d with common denominator ddd. The relation then becomes ∑rjnj=0\sum r_j n_j = 0∑r​j​​n​j​​=0. The next step is to write the numerator polynomials as linear combinations nj=∑iaijmin_j = \sum_i a_{ij} m_in​j​​=∑​i​​a​ij​​m​i​​ of monomials mim_im​i​​ with coefficients aij∈Ka_{ij}\in Ka​ij​​∈K. (The number of monomials is infinite, but we only need to take those that actually occur in any njn_jn​j​​.). The relation ∑jrjnj=∑ijaijrjmi=0\sum_j r_j n_j = \sum_{ij} a_{ij} r_j m_i = 0∑​j​​r​j​​n​j​​=∑​ij​​a​ij​​r​j​​m​i​​=0 is then equivalent to ∑jaijrj=0\sum_j a_{ij}r_j = 0∑​j​​a​ij​​r​j​​=0 for all iii. In other words, the relations are the vectors in the nullspace of the matrix (aij)(a_{ij})(a​ij​​).
text: We start by writing out the $$f_j$$ as fractions $$n_j/d$$ with common denominator $$d$$. The relation then becomes $$\sum r_j n_j = 0$$. The next step is to write the numerator polynomials as linear combinations $$n_j = \sum_i a_{ij} m_i$$ of monomials $$m_i$$ with coefficients $$a_{ij}\in K$$. (The number of monomials is infinite, but we only need to take those that actually occur in any $$n_j$$.). The relation $$\sum_j r_j n_j = \sum_{ij} a_{ij} r_j m_i = 0$$ is then equivalent to $$\sum_j a_{ij}r_j = 0$$ for all $$i$$. In other words, the relations are the vectors in the nullspace of the matrix $$(a_{ij})$$.

html: In order to find only rational relations we replace each linear relation ∑jaijrj=0\sum_j a_{ij} r_j = 0∑​j​​a​ij​​r​j​​=0 where aij∈Ka_{ij}\in Ka​ij​​∈K by a set of linear relations with rational coefficients using a basis of KKK over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. A standard basis is (1,x,x2,…,xn−1)(1, x, x^2, \ldots, x^{n-1})(1,x,x​2​​,…,x​n−1​​) where xxx is a primitive element of KKK and nnn is its degree over Q\mathbb{Q}Q. Each linear relation ∑jajrj=0\sum_j a_j r_j = 0∑​j​​a​j​​r​j​​=0 where aj∈Ka_j\in Ka​j​​∈K can then be written ∑ijcijxirj=0\sum_{ij} c_{ij} x^i r_j = 0∑​ij​​c​ij​​x​i​​r​j​​=0 where aj=∑i=0n−1cijxia_j = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} c_{ij}x^ia​j​​=∑​i=0​n−1​​c​ij​​x​i​​, and this corresponds to the linear system of nnn equations ∑jcijrj=0\sum_j c_{ij} r_j = 0∑​j​​c​ij​​r​j​​=0 with rational coefficients. So the procedure is the following: Each line in the matrix (aij)(a_{ij})(a​ij​​) with entries in KKK shall be replaced with nnn lines having rational coefficients. Then nullspace will produce only rational solutions.
text: In order to find only rational relations we replace each linear relation $$\sum_j a_{ij} r_j = 0$$ where $$a_{ij}\in K$$ by a set of  linear relations with rational coefficients using a basis of $$K$$ over $$\mathbb{Q}$$. A standard basis is $$(1, x, x^2, \ldots, x^{n-1})$$ where $$x$$ is a primitive element of $$K$$ and $$n$$ is its degree over $$\mathbb{Q}$$. Each linear relation $$\sum_j a_j r_j = 0$$ where $$a_j\in K$$ can then be written $$\sum_{ij} c_{ij} x^i r_j = 0$$ where $$a_j = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} c_{ij}x^i$$, and this corresponds to the linear system of $$n$$ equations $$\sum_j c_{ij} r_j = 0$$ with rational coefficients. So the procedure is the following: Each line in the matrix $$(a_{ij})$$ with entries in $$K$$ shall be replaced with $$n$$ lines having rational coefficients. Then `nullspace` will produce only rational solutions.

html: I think that starting from expressions and then using sfield would be the best method for finding the fractions needed for the relations. If there are Polys they should probably be turned to expressions since different Polys are likely to have different domains and generators. A symbol can be a generator in one Poly and in the domain of another Poly. That may be hard to handle without going via expressions.

Good morning, Gaurav.
```
n = K.mod.degree()
zero = QQ.zero
def pad(rep):
    return [zero]*(n - len(rep)) + rep
# replace each row of Kmat with n rows of Qmat
Qmat = []
for row in Kmat:
    Qmat.extend([zip(*[pad(a.rep) for a in row])
```
This is how I'd transform each row of the K-matrix into n rows of the Q-matrix (not tested). K is the domain of the function field: `K = FF.domain`. It can be tested with `K.is_Algebraic`. (If K is QQ, then K-matrix is Q-matrix.) The elements $$a = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} c_i x^i$$  of K  are represented by lists $$[c_k, c_{k-1},\ldots, c_1, c_0]$$ of rational numbers where $$k$$ is the largest integer $$< n$$ such that $$c_k\ne 0$$. `pad` is needed to fill the missing part with zeros. `zip` will make each padded `rep` into a column.

text: Good morning. The second list gives the coefficients of the minimal polynomial $$x^4 - 10x^2 + 1$$. `roots` gives a list of 4 roots one which is $$\sqrt{2\sqrt{6} + 5}$$. (The others are its conjugates, which means that they are algebraically equivalent.) It is easy to see that it can also be written $$\sqrt{2} + \sqrt{3}$$ (by squaring this expression). Now, if this is denoted by $$\xi$$ (as `x` was already taken), then the first list means that the (negative of the) coefficient of `x**2` is $$1/2 \xi^3 - 11/2 \xi$$. (Expand $$\xi^3$$ to see that.)

html: It seems that the addition of θ\thetaθ alone does not suffice in this case for an elementary extension FFF of K(θ)K(\theta)K(θ) containing an element ggg such that f=Dgf = Dgf=Dg. (Here KKK denotes a differential field, not an algebraic field.) Such an FFF is found by integrating f=52x+12tx−3t2xf = \frac{5}{2x} + \frac{1}{2tx} - \frac{3}{t^2x}f=​2x​​5​​+​2tx​​1​​−​t​2​​x​​3​​. The integral of the first term comes from t=logxt = \log{x}t=logx and the last term from θ\thetaθ. A new monomial is needed for the middle term, namely t2=logtt_2 = \log{t}t​2​​=logt. That should then be added to the F list.
text: It seems that the addition of $$\theta$$ alone does not suffice in this case for an elementary extension $$F$$ of $$K(\theta)$$ containing an element $$g$$ such that $$f = Dg$$. (Here $$K$$ denotes a differential field, not an algebraic field.) Such an $$F$$ is found by integrating $$f = \frac{5}{2x} + \frac{1}{2tx} - \frac{3}{t^2x}$$. The integral of the first term comes from $$t = \log{x}$$ and the last term from $$\theta$$. A new monomial is needed for the middle term, namely $$t_2 = \log{t}$$. That should then be added to the `F` list.

           ⌠

           ⎮ ⎜ ⎝x ⎠    ⎟   
x⋅log(x) + ⎮ ⎝ℯ     - 1⎠ dx
           ⌡

html: The behaviour of tan extensions if analogous to that of exp extensions. If we have, e.g., t1=e2xt_1 = e^{2x}t​1​​=e​2x​​ and t2=e3xt_2 = e^{3x}t​2​​=e​3x​​, then they are algebraically related and extension types should be exp resp. alg. That will work fine for the structure theorem, but we have currently no support for the alg extension. The solution is to take t1=ext_1 = e^xt​1​​=e​x​​ and the write e2x=t12e^{2x} = t_1^2e​2x​​=t​1​2​​ and e3x=t13e^{3x} = t_1^3e​3x​​=t​1​3​​. Tangents can be handled similarly. tan2x\tan 2xtan2x and tan3x\tan 3xtan3x are algebraically related but both can be written as rational expressions of tanx\tan xtanx.
text: The behaviour of `tan` extensions if analogous to that of `exp` extensions. If we have, e.g., $$t_1 = e^{2x}$$ and $$t_2 = e^{3x}$$, then they are algebraically related and extension types should be `exp` resp. `alg`. That will work fine for the structure theorem, but we have currently no support for the `alg` extension. The solution is to take $$t_1 = e^x$$ and the write $$e^{2x} = t_1^2$$ and $$e^{3x} = t_1^3$$. Tangents can be handled similarly. $$\tan 2x$$ and $$\tan 3x$$ are algebraically related but both can be written as rational expressions of $$\tan x$$.

html: From Euler's formula it follows that cosnx+isinnx=einx=(eix)n=(cosx+isinx)n=cosnx(1+itanx)n=cosnx(Qn(tanx)+iPn(tanx))\cos nx + i \sin nx = e^{inx} = (e^{ix})^n = (\cos x +i \sin x)^n = \cos^n x (1 + i \tan x)^n = \cos^n x(Q_n(\tan x) + i P_n(\tan x))cosnx+isinnx=e​inx​​=(e​ix​​)​n​​=(cosx+isinx)​n​​=cos​n​​x(1+itanx)​n​​=cos​n​​x(Q​n​​(tanx)+iP​n​​(tanx)) where Pn(t)=(n1)t−(n3)t3+⋯P_n(t) = \binom{n}{1} t - \binom{n}{3} t^3 + \cdotsP​n​​(t)=(​1​n​​)t−(​3​n​​)t​3​​+⋯ and Qn(t)=1−(n2)t2+⋯Q_n(t) = 1 - \binom{n}{2} t^2 + \cdotsQ​n​​(t)=1−(​2​n​​)t​2​​+⋯ by the binomial formula. When the imaginary part is divided by the real part cosnx\cos^n xcos​n​​x cancels and there remains tannx=Pn(tanx)/Qn(tanx)\tan nx = P_n(\tan x)/Q_n(\tan x)tannx=P​n​​(tanx)/Q​n​​(tanx).
text: From Euler's formula it follows that $$\cos nx + i \sin nx = e^{inx} = (e^{ix})^n = (\cos x +i \sin x)^n = \cos^n x (1 + i \tan x)^n = \cos^n x(Q_n(\tan x) + i P_n(\tan x))$$ where $$P_n(t) = \binom{n}{1} t - \binom{n}{3} t^3 + \cdots$$ and $$Q_n(t) = 1 - \binom{n}{2} t^2 + \cdots$$ by the binomial formula. When the imaginary part is divided by the real part $$\cos^n x$$ cancels and there remains $$\tan nx = P_n(\tan x)/Q_n(\tan x)$$.

html: _rewrite_tans will be called repeatedly at each level of the DE under construction to see if some tan can be taken as a new monomial. It will scan newf for tans whose argument is a rational expression of the t-monomials defined earlier. If there are several, the rational relations between the arguments have to be found. If there is a linear relation, its coefficients can be made integers. If a coefficient is equal to one, the corresponding argument is a linear combination with integer coefficients of the other arguments. It should then be rewritten in terms of the other arguments using the addition theorem of tangents.
text: `_rewrite_tans` will be called repeatedly at each level of the DE under construction to see if some `tan` can be taken as a new monomial. It will scan `newf` for `tan`s whose argument is a rational expression of the t-monomials defined earlier. If there are several, the rational relations between the arguments have to be found. If there is a linear relation, its coefficients can be made integers. If a coefficient is equal to one, the corresponding argument is a linear combination with integer coefficients of the other arguments. It should then be rewritten in terms of the other arguments using the addition theorem of tangents.

html: I think that when a differential extension containing a given function is built we could proceed as follows. It there are explicit imaginary constants (in practice, that means I), then all trigonometric functions and their inverses are rewritten in terms of exp and log, Otherwise we assume that everything is real (even if the argument could take complex values) and rewrite those functions in terms of tan and atan. The real form of the structure theorem is valid as long as the constant field is real (does not contain I). If at some point of the construction complex constants are met (though I'm not sure how that could become evident), then we should rewrite everything as exps and logs.
text: I think that when a differential extension containing a given function is built we could proceed as follows. It there are explicit imaginary constants (in practice, that means `I`), then all trigonometric functions and their inverses are rewritten in terms of `exp` and `log`, Otherwise we assume that everything is real (even if the argument could take complex values) and rewrite those functions in terms of `tan` and `atan`. The real form of the structure theorem is valid as long as the constant field is real (does not contain `I`). If at some point of the construction complex constants are met (though I'm not sure how that could become evident), then we should rewrite everything as `exp`s and `log`s.

html: The indefinite integral constructed by Risch's algorithm are elements of differential fields that are elementary extensions of the rational function field. Its elements are expressed in terms of tan, atan, etc. Since atan is multivalued, it already takes all the values that the paper defines. The role of the floor function is to combine suitable branches on certain intervals to get a continuous function on the real line.

html: Something like that will be needed for tangents. It would be a part of _rerwrite_tan. That could be the second step in a two-step process parallel to handling of exp. The first step will be collecting all tan arguments into groups such that the arguments in one group are rational multiples of each other. Then, for each group, one expression is chosen such that all arguments are its integral multiples. That is what integer_powers does. Then all tangents in a group are rewritten as rational expressions of the tangent of the chosen expression. Similar process is already implemented in _rewrite_exp. For example, exp2x\exp 2xexp2x and exp3x\exp 3xexp3x become (expx)2(\exp x)^2(expx)​2​​ and (expx)3(\exp x)^3(expx)​3​​.
text: Something like that will be needed for tangents. It would be a part of _rerwrite_tan. That could be the second step in a two-step process parallel to handling of exp. The first step will be collecting all tan arguments into groups such that the arguments in one group are rational multiples of each other. Then, for each group, one expression is chosen such that all arguments are its integral multiples. That is what `integer_powers` does. Then all tangents in a group are rewritten as rational expressions of the tangent of the chosen expression. Similar process is already implemented in `_rewrite_exp`. For example, $$\exp 2x$$ and $$\exp 3x$$ become $$(\exp x)^2$$ and $$(\exp x)^3$$.

html: This step should be implemented first. The number of arguments will be reduced. The second step would then consist of finding rational linear relations among the remaining arguments. For each relation it is possible to replace one tangent as a rational function of the others. After no relations remain, the remaining tangents will be algebraically independent by the structure theorem and can be used as new t-variables.

html: integer_power will find the 'easy' algebraic dependencies. That should be used to cut down the number of tans whenever possible. It is harder to find algebraic dependencies between tans whose arguments are not rational multiples of each other. For that it is necessary to find the linear relations with rational coefficients between several arguments. For example, if we have tan(x)\tan(x)tan(x), tan(x2)\tan(x^2)tan(x​2​​) and tan(x+x2)\tan(x + x^2)tan(x+x​2​​), then the last one should be eliminated by means of the addition formula of tan.
text: `integer_power` will find the 'easy' algebraic dependencies. That should be used to cut down the number of tans whenever possible. It is harder to find algebraic dependencies between tans whose arguments are not rational multiples of each other. For that it is necessary to find the linear relations with rational coefficients between several arguments. For example, if we have $$\tan(x)$$, $$\tan(x^2)$$ and $$\tan(x + x^2)$$, then the last one should be eliminated by means of the addition formula of tan.

html: Most CASes try to compute integrals using special functions, rather than just giving up when something is nonelementary. They're mainly interested in giving some kind of answer when possible. Nonelementaryness is generally only of academic interest. Furthermore, only one integration algorithm (the Risch algorithm) is able to prove nonelementaryness. Other algorithms such as pattern matching algorithms don't do such things.

>>> DE = DifferentialExtension(extension=dict(T=[x, t0, t1], D=[Poly(1, x), Poly(2*x*t0, t0), Poly(2/sqrt(pi)/t0, t1)], fa=Poly(t1, t1), fd=Poly(1, t1), Tfunc
... s=[Lambda(x, exp(x**2)), Lambda(x, erf(x))], backsubs=[]))
>>> risch_integrate(erf(x), x, DE)
Integral((2*sqrt(pi)*x**2*exp(x**2)*erf(x) + 2*x - sqrt(pi)*exp(x**2)*erf(x))*exp(-x**2)/(2*sqrt(pi)*x**2), x) - erf(x)/(2*x)
>>> integrate(erf(x), x)
x*erf(x) + exp(-x**2)/sqrt(pi)
text:
```
>>> DE = DifferentialExtension(extension=dict(T=[x, t0, t1], D=[Poly(1, x), Poly(2*x*t0, t0), Poly(2/sqrt(pi)/t0, t1)], fa=Poly(t1, t1), fd=Poly(1, t1), Tfunc
... s=[Lambda(x, exp(x**2)), Lambda(x, erf(x))], backsubs=[]))
>>> risch_integrate(erf(x), x, DE)
Integral((2*sqrt(pi)*x**2*exp(x**2)*erf(x) + 2*x - sqrt(pi)*exp(x**2)*erf(x))*exp(-x**2)/(2*sqrt(pi)*x**2), x) - erf(x)/(2*x)
>>> integrate(erf(x), x)
x*erf(x) + exp(-x**2)/sqrt(pi)
```

>>> from sympy.integrals.risch import DifferentialExtension, risch_integrate
>>> DE = DifferentialExtension(extension={'f': x*exp(-x**2)*erf(x), 'D': [Poly(1, x), Poly(-2*x*t0, t0), Poly(t0, t1)], 'T':[x, t0, t1], 'fa': Poly(x*t0*t1, t1), 'fd': Poly(1, t1), 'Tfuncs': [lambda x: exp(-x**2), lambda x: erf(x)]})
>>> risch_integrate(x*exp(-x**2)*erf(x), x, extension=DE)
text:
```py
>>> from sympy.integrals.risch import DifferentialExtension, risch_integrate
>>> DE = DifferentialExtension(extension={'f': x*exp(-x**2)*erf(x), 'D': [Poly(1, x), Poly(-2*x*t0, t0), Poly(t0, t1)], 'T':[x, t0, t1], 'fa': Poly(x*t0*t1, t1), 'fd': Poly(1, t1), 'Tfuncs': [lambda x: exp(-x**2), lambda x: erf(x)]})
>>> risch_integrate(x*exp(-x**2)*erf(x), x, extension=DE)
```
